Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Feldman’s voice rose, sharp and suspicious. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? Explain every detail!” My script fluttered in my hand, but I knew I had to go off-script, answer every question, keep him calm—my supervisor expected nothing less. My stomach rumbled, reminding me I’d skipped lunch. I glanced at the clock: only a few minutes until my break. I’d packed matzo and hummus, kosher, of course, just like my mother taught me. But if I put Mr. Feldman on hold, he might hang up, and I’d lose a sale. If I stayed, I’d miss my only chance to eat before the next round of calls. My mind raced—my job demanded patience and persistence, but my faith asked me to honor my body and my traditions. The pressure built in my chest as I tried to focus on Mr. Feldman’s questions, my hunger gnawing at my resolve, torn between the demands of my work and the quiet, steady pull of my beliefs.
